title: Weave's Application Video for YC W14
author: Y Combinator
description:
Today, Weave, which was part of YC’s W14 batch, is going public. This is their YC application video from 2014.

When Weave applied to YC, they supplied dentists with an all-in-one customer communications and management system. But their vision was always a larger one. Today, the company still supports dental offices, but also optometrists, vets, and other medical offices with similar capabilities. Tens of thousands of professional offices around the United States and Canada run their businesses using Weave.

Read about their journey at https://blog.ycombinator.com/weave-w14-is-going-public/.

title: Applying to Y Combinator? 3 tips from a former YC partner
author: Garry Tan
description:
Hi, I'm Garry Tan, former Y Combinator partner, Forbes Midas List top venture capitalist and cofounder at Initialized Capital. We were earliest investors in billion dollar startups like Coinbase and Instacart. I'm doing my own run-and-gun one man YouTube channel with no staff or crew - we're going for raw and unfiltered and high signal in order to help you with your building your world-changing startup.

In this episode I want to talk about what advice I always give to people writing their YC applications. Watch to the end you'll find a link to submit your YC app to me for comments and review. I can guarantee I'll read the first 100 responses from YouTube, but honestly I'll try my best overall just because I really want to help. 

Y Combinator changed my life and I hope it changes yours. 

Please like this video and subscribe to my channel if you want to see more videos like this!

Find Garry on Twitter at https://twitter.com/garrytan

Learn more about the companies we fund, and how we work with them at https://initialized.com

title: Embark Trucks' Application Video for YC W16
author: Y Combinator
description:
After building the first self-driving vehicle in Canada, three students from the University of Waterloo applied to Y Combinator's Winter 2016 batch with their company, Varden Labs, intending to build self-driving shuttles for use on campuses. 

They were accepted, and eventually went on to become Embark Trucks, which builds self-driving software for the $700B trucking industry. Today, they're going public. This is their YC application video from 2016.

Read about their road to IPO at https://blog.ycombinator.com/embark-trucks-going-public/.

title: Cyder (YC W2022) Application Video
author: Cyder
description:
Cyder is the world's first data trust that makes it simple and free for users to protect their privacy, control their data, and earn royalties - while enabling organizations to access permission-based, ethically sourced, reliable first-party data. 

Learn more and join the waitlist at: https://www.getcyder.com/

At Cyder we believe:
1. you own your data, not big tech companies
2. you should be paid whenever it is used
3. you shouldn't have to change how you browse
​
We took these principles and built a data trust that provides members control of and compensation for the data they share.
​
Our business model is actually quite simple, we work in the background of your browser to collect insights (most of which are already collected by companies like Google and Facebook) and reward you, our members, whenever your data is used. Of course, you will continue to own your data throughout the process and update your preferences in our robust data privacy dashboard.

This video was created as a submission for YCombinator W2022

Learn more at getcyder.com
CoFounded by: Sukhman Dulay (https://ca.linkedin.com/in/sukhmandulay) & Will Christodoulou (https://ca.linkedin.com/in/will-christodoulou)

https://www.getcyder.com/
getcyder@gmail.com
Cyder Inc. 2021
Control Your Data & Earn Rewards

description:
BruYou Y Combinator S2022 Application Video

BruYou is the app for sending and receiving drinks. 

Looking for a way to send drinks to friends with your phone?

Through BruYou, you can now remotely buy any friend a drink anytime from any participating bar, restaurant, brewery, distillery, or winery. 

BruYou is the only app to send & receive drinks in a fun and social way. It's quick and easy to use, and allows you to buy drinks for your friends and family at any time, with just a few clicks.

- Want to send a little birthday gift? 
- Want to celebrate a special event like a graduation, but cannot be there in person?
- Getting married and want to solicit drinks for your bachelorette or bachelor party?
- Want to thank someone with a small gift? 
- Trying to entice your friends to join you for happy hour?
- Want to grab the next round for your friends, but can't be there in person?
- Love sharing newly discovered breweries, bars, distilleries, wineries and restaurants with fellow drinkers?

Send them a drink through BruYou!

Additionally, our streamlined partner signup process allows any US-based bar, restaurant, brewery, distillery, or winery to join our network and start selling in as little as 5 minutes. Simply signup at https://www.bruyouapp.com/register, sync your business bank account through our secure payments API, and add drinks to your menu and publish your business on the app.

Download the app for free and start sending drinks today at https://www.bruyouapp.com/ or join our partner bar network by signing up at https://www.bruyouapp.com/register.

title: Mys Tyler - Application to Y Combinator Winter 2021
author: Mys Tyler
description:
Y Combinator (YC) is arguably the most prestigious and credible startup accelerator globally. Based in Silicon Valley, it's been a critical part of the journey for many of the who's who in the startup world including Stripe, Airbnb, Dropbox, and Reddit.

As an early stage startup, with a global vision, we (Mys Tyler) would LOVE to be a part of the YC program - with access to some of the best coaching and mentoring, an incredible network, and the stamp of approval that getting into YC affords - we want to change the way people shop, and YC will get us that much closer to realizing our vision. 

YC is very competitive, the rumored acceptance rate is 1.5%, so that makes it harder to get into than Stanford. Part of the application process, is a pitch video from the founder/ founding team. This is ours :)

title: TLDR (YC S2020) Application Video
author: Manuel Korfmann
description:
Rejection email from YCombinator:

Thanks for applying to Y Combinator. We're sorry to say that your startup was not selected to interview for the upcoming Y Combinator batch. Please don't take it personally. We carefully reviewed thousands of applications and since there's a limit on the number of startups we can interview in person, we had to turn away a lot of promising companies.

Unfortunately, we can't give you individual feedback about your application. (This page explains why)[http://email.email.ycombinator.com/c/eJwVjcsKwyAURL8mLovvx8JFN_2NcmOuja3RYCwlf18DA3NmGJjFS8mjIskrXJzmOoB1Ep9G48IUi8Faw6mFSdJUOrYC-bZBymT1FBkYCCGyaFFQ4zRqMRsFTqAAbkj2a-_7JO4TfwydoW5zKtBruw0czW89S-0DSPMblC_mT21xUJHj73X9XEvSPex7TgF6quUY8eCU0-EN3xj6H-5cPtI].

We hope you reapply for the next batch; in fact, we encourage it. The next batch will run from January–March 2021 and the deadline to apply for it is in September 2020. Applying multiple times does not count against you and a surprisingly large number of companies are funded after applying more than once. Over 50% of the startups we accept are repeat applicants.

We also encourage you to check out Y Combinator’s Startup School. It’s a free online course that keeps you focused on improving your startup. Sign up at startupschool.org.

Best of luck,

—YC

title: Provide Now - Y Combinator Summer 2020 Application Video
author: Alexandra Taylor
description:
Provide Now is a Seattle-based nonprofit (pending 501c3 status) marketplace that allows donors to purchase gifts-in-kind needed by local charitable organizations. Our mission is to promote transparent donations of material items to equip nonprofits and communities with the resources necessary to thrive. 

Closed Captioning (for those with audio impairment)

My name is Gigi Gillie and I am the co-founder and CEO of Provide Now. I am reporting to you with my co-founder from our separate quarantined spaces. 

My name is Alex Taylor and I am the co-founder and COO of Provide Now 

Provide Now creates donations registries for nonprofits. We list material items that local charities need, and donors can purchase items for those nonprofits. 

We are not diverting monetary donations to nonprofits but rather increasing donorship from individuals who are driven by the impact of purchasing an item. So instead of donating $10, you can purchase a bag of dog food and know that 100% of your donation has gone towards feeding a dog. 

The baby boomers are expected to leave $30 trillion in wealth to the younger generations. These younger generations are going to expect a transparent, modern philanthropic experience driven by social media, and we aim to provide that. 

As a donor with Provide Now, you know exactly who you are donating to, what they genuinely need, and where your money is going.

title: I pitched my startup to Y Combinator (startup accelerator) for $150,000 and got rejected.
author: Life of Luba
description:
In this video I share my first-hand experience interviewing with the most famous startup accelerator in the world – Y Combinator. I address my learnings from being rejected by Y Combinator and being denied $150,000.
What is Y Combinator?

YC provides seed funding for startups. This accelerator program is based in the heart of innovative tech, Silicon Valley. YC has been used to launch companies such as: Stripe, Airbnb, DoorDash, Coinbase, Instacart, Dropbox and Twitch, Cruise Automation, and many more. Once accepted into the program, not only do you get money for your business idea, but you also gain the support of YC partners and the YC community. Founders participate in bi-weekly office hours, and have weekly talks from VCs, prominent founders, and executives.

Some of the current YC partners include:
Michael Seibel - cofounder of Twitch
Eric Migicovsky -founder of Pebble
Gustaf Alstromer – growth product lead at Airbnb
Paul Buchheit – creator of Gmail

My partner and I had a new business idea; one that would provide a platform to help creators from YouTube, Instagram, other influencers and teachers monetize their live content.

This is what the Y Combinator application looks like https://apply.ycombinator.com/app/edit

I've broken down the YC application and YC interview process as follows:
The idea: the application will make you think about your idea in terms of
Why did you choose this particular idea?
How do you plan to grow your business?
How do you plan on increasing user acquisition?
How do you plan on making money?
How does this product differ from what the competition is doing?

Going over who is all collaborating on this project
The team members -- leadership, management, key players

How invested will you be on working on this project? Is it a side hustle or will you prioritize this venture as your focus and main source of income?

Keep in mind that during this process over 15,000 applications were submitted and only 500 were selected to interview.

The interview lead was by Michael Seibel (cofounder of Twitch and now board member of Reddit)
Before the interview I did not know who would be interviewing us, all I did know was that it would be 3-4 YC partners.Try to stand out in the interview, but don't stress. The interview was very conversational rather than a straight questionnaire -- the whole situation felt very relaxing in an unconventional way.

That same day I got an email from Michael Seibel asking about the timing of a prototype. 

The 25-minute call with Michael
We discussed how we emphasized marketing too heavily and how we should focus more on getting the technical prototype

The rejection
2 days after our call, we received the infamous Y Combinator rejection letter which included feedback on why we didn't get in
Although it was a cool product, we were not the right founders for it

The main lessons learned
Know your product
Know your customer
Know your angle and how that differs from your competitors
You need to live and breathe your product or service
You need to obsessively think about it
Work on it, test it, improve it -- night and day
 
I'm grateful for YC and Michael Seibel taking a chance on interviewing us. If you are on a startup journey yourself, don't give up, believe in yourself and your ideas. Do not be afraid to apply to startup funding programs like Y Combinator!

This is the first video of a series intended to act as a guide to help you entrepreneurs, small business owners, or anyone interested in businesses learn about what it takes to get funding for your incredible ideas.
If you have any further questions regarding the YC application and interview process go ahead and leave it in the comment box and I'll make sure to answer your questions as best I can!

Don't forget to like and subscribe if you haven't already and click the notification bell to alert you when I post more entrepreneurial videos in the future.

Stay tuned for more content related to entrepreneurship, motivation, business, real estate investing, startup, seed funding, crowdfunding, personal education, online education, self-improvement, tech.

title: Olive Branch Pictures MassChallenge 3-Minute Pitch Video
author: Olive Branch Pictures Inc.
description:
Humans are the only species capable of telling stories. These mythologies, religious texts, literature, and histories have formed value and behavior systems throughout civilization. 

We believe that multi-narrative, representational, ideologically-balanced stories can build trust and understanding between groups caught in intractable conflict. 

Welcome to Olive Branch Pictures

A production studio for cultural diplomacy, entertainment-education, and philanthropy through  comics and animated movies developed by a talented team and advisory board selected for representation and ideological balance. 

Our first production addresses the Israeli-Palestinian Conflict with Shira and Amal: The story of two young women, one Israeli, one Palestinian, who use music to cope with trauma and bring peace to Jerusalem.

Our mission is to improve conditions for long-term positive negotiations and policy change as well as build professional and institutional relationships across the ideological spectrum

Over the next 12 months, we will develop Shira and Amal as a graphic novel capable of sensitively navigating the controversies of the conflict to reach diverse stakeholders and then scale our IP into an Animated Musical Feature Film over the following three years and establish a sustainable animation studio to mediate other conflicts. 

Since incorporating in October 2018 we’ve established strategic partnerships, a representational team including Khaled Abousheikh from Gaza, Noa Bendahan from Tel Aviv, and Bashar Bakri from East Jerusalem, and advisors including the former South African Ambassador to the Palestinian Authority Raf Gangat, and Palestinian Sesame Street Creator Daoud Kuttab, we’ve developed the prototype and a 56-page Theory of Change, won competitions at Brandeis and Drexel University, and EO GSEA Connecticut, completed the Watson Institute Accelerator, raised over 15 thousand dollars, interviewed over 100 potential customers and stakeholders, and we are currently part of the 50:50 Startups Incubator which brings Israelis and Palestinians together to build equally-owned startups  

Olive Branch Pictures uses a hybrid B-Corp model with a 501c3 Wing donating 10-20% of profit to diverse regional Non-profit partners decided by our customers, engaging them in the peacebuilding process.

We will apply best practices in impact measurement under organizations such as the Palestinian Center for Policy & Survey Research and Harmony Labs. 

Our goal is to reach at least 2M customers and 2 million stakeholders with the graphic novel which would be subsidized or donation-based in target dialect versions.

title: 500 Startups Application
author: Hugh Malkin
description:
A video of our founders presenting the Hugecity opportunity. Luckily, production value was not important. 

Company: Hugecity
Website: www.hugecity.us
iPhone App: https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/hugecity/id643054922
Founders: Hugh Malkin, Adam Wilson, Jonathan Nesbitt
Location: Goat Farm, Outside Hugecity Office
Length: 3 Min Max

Trends:
- Wealth is no longer being shown by the things you own, but the experiences you share on Facebook
- 80% of America's population is urban and it's growing
- We are seeking and creating the lives we used to only think was possible in "HUGE" cities
- Today, any city can be a huge city

Problem:
Its 2013 we know that amazing things are happening around us but there is no way to discover every event all of the time. These great events are not getting the audience they deserve.

Event sites like Sosh, YPlan, and Meetup all run into three main problems: Data, Scalability, and Curation.

Hugecity has solved all of these problems by using the 16 million events created on Facebook each month. Facebook is the first place anyone creates an evzSyent because it is the easiest way to share an event. It is up to date because the event managers are directly managing the information for the event. Data is not a problem.

On May 10th we launched our app, website and email that allows anyone in any city in the world to discover what is happening around them and where their friends are going. We have hundreds of events in every city in the world every day. We have quickly grown to 150,000 monthly visitors and we are still going. Scalability is not a problem. 

Everyone's Hugecity is different because we tailor the events we show to each user using their Facebook friends and likes. A user never has to ask their friends to join or tell us what they like. Curation is not a problem. 

We are a team of 4 and we have built a global curated event discovery engine that has solved all three problems that every event site has run into before.

So, lets talk money. The event promotion industry is worth $24B in the US. In the past few weeks we have manually sold $1000 worth of event promotions to 15 customers. 

We want to come to 500 Startups to automate our sales and grow to launch Hugecity into a viable business.

title: How do I submit a successful application to 500 startups?
author: Startupedia
description:
Edith Yeung, Partner, Mobile Collective at 500 Startups explains how to put together a successful application to 500 Startups. 

Prior to 500, Edith ran marketing for Dolphin Browser, a Sequoia-backed company with over 150M installs. She was also an active angel investor focusing on mobile. Edith also worked with numerous evil empires such as Siebel, AMS, AT&T Wireless, Autodesk. In her copious spare time, Edith curates a mobile newsletter.

Transcript:

How do I submit a successful application to 500 startups?

We have written many many posts I highly encourage you guys to go to our blog for specific advice. I think in general, we don't really purely fund an idea. Because I focus on mobile, we usually don’t invest in things if you haven’t launched and I'm really hoping that in your application you’ll be able to speak more on metrics. Everybody talks about tractions but particularly with mobile if you’re mobile app, B2C focused. Definitely put down what’s your install, what's your monthly active users, what's your daily active users. I wanna know a founder who keeps track of that and should be especially for early-stage where you measure for success and growth. 

Also, I think in general, most investors are lazy. They want to know how much do you know the market landscape of what you are working on. So it’s not purely talking about yourself, but be able to articulate it. Ok, we know that this one, two, three companies are working on this, but this is what set us apart, this is what differentiates us and why. The way you article it, how you describe some of these metrics and where's your place in the world will set you apart in your application.

Learn more at http://siliconvalleyforum.com/startupedia/funding

title: At what stage of my startup can I apply to 500 startups?
author: Startupedia
description:
Edith Yeung, Partner, Mobile Collective at 500 Startups explains at what stage you should be at with your startup to qualify to apply to 500 Startups. 

Prior to 500, Edith ran marketing for Dolphin Browser, a Sequoia-backed company with over 150M installs. She was also an active angel investor focusing on mobile. Edith also worked with numerous evil empires such as Siebel, AMS, AT&T Wireless, Autodesk. In her copious spare time, Edith curates a mobile newsletter.

Transcript:

At what stage of my startup can I apply to 500 startups?

We absolutely encourage after launch, and that's particularly for B2C. Most of the app developers I know can launch apps over a weekend and just wait for approval. If you’re a B2B focused on business, we would like to see at least two or three pilot customers, because usually takes much longer circles and it’s even harder for us to invest in that enterprise-focused things. But having said that, still, I don't want to discourage you but at least do something, do some customer development first before you apply. So I wouldn't say like if you pure idea stage probably not but after lunch and when before you raise your first round. We’re very open would love to have you apply because going through that process at least you know what we ask even if you don't get accepted that process is really valuable. We’re very open to chat with you and to give you guys advise.

Learn more at http://siliconvalleyforum.com/startupedia/funding

A self-described Opendoor for short-term rental, the company, can furnish homes in just 48hrs and make their property available for bookings. Vacayo is the first company adding new supply to meet the growing vacation rental demand, a $51 billion total addressable market in the US.

author: 500 Global
description:

Numa isn't just a firewall - it's much more than that. Where firewalls just look at the envelope, Numa takes an x-ray. Numa M isn't just a way to see what's going on with your network, it protects your phone wherever you go, without draining your battery.

Numa stops attacks that antivirus software can't. It keeps malicious traffic from getting in in the first place, so it protects connected devices such as thermostats, refrigerators, IP cameras, and control systems.

Numa is security for the next generation of Internet applications. Our devices are getting smarter. Shouldn't our networks, too?

title: cc ELEVATOR PITCH U - Nicole Glaros -- TechStars
author: th.ai
description:
Hi my name is Nicole Glaros and I'm the
managing director for TechStars here in Boulder
and welcome to another edition of TechStars U.
Today we're going to talk about elevator pitches
now elevator pitches are fundamental building block
to communicating the value of your startup
but so many entrepreneurs suck at it
as soon as you start giving your elevator pitch
what most people hear is
bla bla bla bla startup
bla bla bla bla social media platform
bla bla bla bla API
they're just not listening because
entrepreneurs have not figured out how to effectively communicate their elevator pitch
so today we're gonna give you a really quick summary of how to do this effectively
so first of all what is an elevator pitch?
.
it's a twenty to thirty second summary of your business in one to two sentences
and the goal of an elevator pitch is to effectively communicate what it is that you do
and also get engagement from your audience
so you are trying to get questions asked back
so let's talk about the framework for your elevator pitch
so the framework is
for customers with [problem x] we [what you do]
so let me say that again
for customers with [problem x] we [what you do]
so let's use a couple examples
Rent Monitor is a company from 2010 TechStars class
now if we use this framework their elevator pitch would look something like this:
for landlords who are overcome with the burden of managing rental properties
Rent Monitor provides a web service platform
that allows the automation of many commonly occurring manual tasks
such as rent collection and maintenance requests
let's use a second example
something that's near and dear to all of our hearts
TechStars
so if TechStars used this framework for their elevator pitch it would sound something like this
Startups fail 95% of the time.
TechStars provides capital and mentorship in a 13 week boot camp that will turn that 95% failure rate into a 92% success rate
now notice in both of those examples I did not use what we are I always use what we do
and the reason for that is simple because
many people don't understand the lingo of today's technology
so for TechStars we are a seed accelerator
but I never use that in our elevator pitch, why?
because if you don't know what a seed accelerator is
you might think hey, cool they grow seeds
so always talk about what you do, not what you are
so now that you have the framework down, what you need to do is
write down five to ten versions of your elevator pitch
and then practice against a real audience
make sure you're getting feedback from them
listen to the questions that people ask
and iterate on this framework until you've got a really solid pitch
once the pitch is solid you wanna
practice practice practice
until everybody on your team can say it consistently 100% of the time
everybody should have it memorized wordforword
once you have that done then you want to start paying attention to people's questions
so questions are going to be indicative of how well they understand what you're talking about and
you wanna practice those answers because clearly
a short succinct answer to a question indicates how well you know your product and your market so in summary
your elevator pitch should be one to two sentences no more than thirty seconds max
you want to iterate until solid
practice until consistent
and then practice your answers
and that will give you a very solid elevator pitch
this is Nicole Glaros from TechStars signing off
thanks for attending TechStars U.
.
source: youtu.be/4FB8-KiYFqQ

title: TechStars Startup Weekend Pitch Competition
author: TCNewTech
description:
This is the grand finale event of Northern Michigan Startup Week. Attend this Demo Day event to watch the Techstars Startup Weekend teams pitch their startups to a panel of judges for a chance to win startup glory.

Join us for the Startup Weekend Pitch Competition and see what amazing progress our Startup Weekend Teams have made in just one weekend of hard work. The teams will pitch their ideas and what they've created. Our team of judges will ask questions, convene and then declare the winners of Traverse City Startup Weekend 2022.

Techstars Startup Weekend is an exciting and immersive foray into the world of startups. Over an action-packed three days, participants meet the very best mentors, investors, co-founders and sponsors to learn how to get more done faster — and, maybe even start that business.

Startup Weekend is a 54-hour educational event, which helps to educate, support, and empower people to become entrepreneurs.

About Northern Michigan Startup Week

Happening May 9-15, 2022, Northern Michigan Startup Week is a celebration of entrepreneurship, innovation, and the growing startup community in Traverse City and throughout the region. Everyone is invited to discover new opportunities and foster big ideas that are happening right here in Northern Michigan. Events include Space Night, Funding Innovation Luncheon, Startup Expo, University Idea Showcase, Student Pitch Competition, and TechStars Startup Weekend.

Northern Michigan Startup Week is a collaborative initiative organized by 20Fathoms, TCNewTech, Northern Michigan Angels, and Newton's Road.

Lead sponsors are Hagerty, Boomerang Catapult, and Northwestern Michigan College. The media sponsor is Interlochen Public Radio.

title: Grand Pitching Finale | Techstars Startup Weekend Sustainability Selangor 2022 (TSSW)
author: Taylor's University Student Council
description:
Techstars Startup Weekend is a 54-hour event designed to provide superior experiential education for technical and non-technical entrepreneurs. Beginning with Friday night pitches and continuing through brainstorming, business plan development, and basic prototype creation, Techstars Startup Weekends culminate in Sunday night demos and presentations. 

Participants create working startups during the event and are able to collaborate with like-minded individuals outside of their daily networks. All teams will hear talks by industry leaders and receive valuable feedback from local entrepreneurs. The weekend is centred around action, innovation, and education. Whether you are looking for feedback on an idea, a co-founder, specific skill sets, or a team to help you execute, Techstars Startup Weekends are the perfect environment in which to test your idea and take the first steps towards launching your own startup.

title: Our 2012 AngelPad Application for Storefront
author: Tristan Pollock
description:
"Hello AngelPad! We're Storefront co-founders Erik Eliason and Tristan Pollock."

This is the video that got us into AngelPad's 5th cohort in Fall 2012 with our startup Storefront. The entire cohort was 12 startups out of 2,000+ that applied. At the time of recording, we were in Minnesota in my apartment working on the MVP and getting our first customers and spaces listed.

Since this video, we raised $10M in venture capital for Storefront and sold it to OuiOpen who runs it to this day.
